diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Often, it starts with flu-like symptoms, then a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, followed by the top layer of the skin dying, shedding, and then healing. SJS often involves the eyes, and it can lead to blindness.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A severe skin condition that causes the skin to blister and peel off, leading to a rash that can cover much of the body. It is often triggered by an adverse reaction to drugs. TEN is like Stevens-Johnson Syndrome but more severe. It also typically involves the mucous membranes and can lead to severe eye problems and systemic infection.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction that occurs typically 2-8 weeks after exposure to certain medications. It is characterized by a fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, hematological abnormalities (such as eosinophilia or atypical lymphocytosis), and organ involvement (such as hepatitis, nephritis, or myocarditis).

diagnoses.name: Acute Bacterial Pyelonephritis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the kidney, usually caused by E. coli bacteria. Symptoms may include fever, chills, flank pain, painful urination, and pyuria. The condition can also lead to systemic symptoms such as leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. It is characterized by fever, conjunctivitis, rash, swollen hands and feet, redness of the mouth, lips, and throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy. If untreated, it can lead to serious cardiovascular complications.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladders, or urethra. Symptoms include a strong, persistent urge to urinate, a burning sensation when urinating, passing frequent, small amounts of urine, and pyuria.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. Caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria, it's characterized by a bright red rash covering most of the body, sore throat, and high fever. It can affect the kidneys and lead to leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage tissues in various parts of the body, including skin (rashes), joints, and kidneys. It can present with a wide range of symptoms, including fever, rashes, joint pain, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can vary and might include mouth and genital ulcers, eye inflammation, arthritis, and skin rashes. It's a chronic condition that may cause complications such as eye damage and vascular problems.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, abdominal pain, and arthritis. It most commonly affects children. The rash typically is purple and is related to vasculitis; kidney involvement may lead to hematuria or proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive sleep apnea
diagnoses.description: A common sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep due to throat muscles intermittently relaxing and blocking the airway.

diagnoses.name: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition marked by persistent inattention, hyperactivity, and sometimes impulsivity.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhoids
diagnoses.description: Swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that cause discomfort and bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Sensorineural hearing loss
diagnoses.description: A type of hearing loss in which the root cause lies in the inner ear or sensory organ (cochlea and associated structures) or the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII).

diagnoses.name: Otitis externa
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the outer ear canal, often referred to as swimmer's ear.
common_treatments: Ear drops containing antibiotics and steroids

diagnoses.name: Chronic venous insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Occurs when your leg veins don't allow blood to flow back up to your heart. Hemorrhoids can be a manifestation of chronic venous insufficiency.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which can cause a wide range of symptoms including changes in energy level or mood.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Chronic otitis media with effusion
diagnoses.description: Inflammation and fluid retention in the middle ear, which may follow acute otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: Open sores that develop on the inside lining of your stomach and the upper portion of your small intestine.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where one or more tumors form in your pancreas or the upper part of your small intestine (duodenum) which may cause ulcers and high acid production.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and produces excessive amounts of thyroid hormone, which may cause hyperactivity among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges, often leading to infertility.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, which can lead to damage in the small intestine and various symptoms including ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that forms the lining of your uterus grows outside of your uterine cavity, leading to infertility among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Helicobacter pylori Infection
diagnoses.description: A type of bacterial infection in the stomach that is often a leading cause of ulcers worldwide.

diagnoses.name: Functional Dyspepsia
diagnoses.description: Also known as non-ulcer stomach pain, it's a term for recurring signs and symptoms of indigestion that have no obvious cause.

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition that often results from stress and presents similarly to a heart attack, with no coronary artery blockage.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time, which can contribute to electrolyte imbalances, hypertension, and other systemic complications.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure that's a consequence of another medical condition such as chronic kidney disease, which can lead to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet, leading to hyperferritinemia; excess iron is stored in the organs, especially the liver, heart, and pancreas.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the heart and kidneys, possibly leading to conditions like Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various disorders affecting the nervous system that could explain dysosmia (distortions in the sense of smell).

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus that may lead to symptoms including dysosmia and can also impact the cardiovascular system, potentially leading to conditions like Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can be associated with systemic features such as chronic anemia and increased ferritin levels.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to metabolic disturbances that can affect blood pressure regulation and kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare, usually benign tumor of adrenal gland tissue that results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that regulate heart rate and blood pressure, possibly leading to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses: Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, folate deficiency)
Infection (e.g., viral, bacterial, such as Helicobacter pylori associated with ulcers)
Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, which may cause ulcers)
Endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism, which can cause weight gain and dysgeusia)
Oral health issues (e.g., gingivitis or periodontitis, which can lead to ulcers)
Rheumatologic disorders (e.g., Sjögren’s syndrome, which can cause dysgeusia)
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) or other hematologic conditions associated with monocytosis

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reason: Bronchitis is a core component of COPD, with symptoms that go beyond just the acute episodes.

diagnoses.name: Acute Bronchitis
diagnoses.reason: Immediate diagnosis considering the bronchitis symptom, often viral or bacterial.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Mood lability can be a key symptom of bipolar disorder, which is characterized by extreme mood swings.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Mood lability can also be present as a symptom of major depression, indicating severe and episodic mood swings.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)
diagnoses.reason: This genetic disorder involves arteriovenous malformations and can cause a wide spectrum of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Lymphadenitis might be a symptom in the context of lymphoma, given the involvement of lymph node inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Directly related to the symptom of obstructive sleep apnea, a condition that disrupts normal sleep breathing patterns.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: This condition can cause lymphadenitis and has been associated with pulmonary manifestations and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reason: Often presents with lymphadenitis, and could also be associated with fatigue that complicates sleep disorders.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Mood lability may also appear in various anxiety disorders, affecting mood regulation.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)
Vitamin D Deficiency (could be related to CKD and Malabsorption)
Iron Deficiency Anemia (could be related to CKD, Endometriosis, and Malabsorption)

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute lower respiratory infection

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)
Secondary Immunodeficiency (due to underlying disease, medication, etc.)
Secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic renal failure
Skin Tags (if 'tags' refers to skin conditions)
Reactive Thrombocytosis Secondary to Inflammation or Infection
Severe allergic reaction (not specified as anaphylaxis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with skin involvement
Allergic Rhinitis (due to the symptom of nasal congestion)
Epilepsy (for symptom correlation with incontinence during a seizure)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (rare cause, presenting with Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms before the onset of headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke but lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location, and growth rate.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur if you have diabetes. High blood sugar (glucose) can injure nerves throughout your body.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from the restricted blood flow to the back part of the brain, which is responsible for many bodily functions including balance and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica (Devic's Disease)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the optic nerves and spinal cord, leading to vision loss and spinal cord dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (such as scotoma), sensory symptoms, and other forms of aura. Vertigo, diplopia, and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound) can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause vertigo, blurred or double vision (diplopia), and partial vision loss (scotoma).

diagnoses.name: Basilar-type Migraine
diagnoses.description: A form of migraine that starts in the brainstem or involves the two back areas of the brain (the cerebellum). It often presents with vertigo, double vision, and sometimes phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, patients might experience tinnitus or aural fullness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Symptoms can include temporary blindness in one eye (scotoma), dizziness or vertigo, and double vision.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from poor blood flow to the back of the brain that can lead to symptoms such as vertigo, double vision, and scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including vertigo, visual disturbances like scotoma and diplopia, and sensitivity to sound.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the vestibular nerve that can cause severe, sudden vertigo. Patients might also experience balance difficulties and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness usually triggered by specific changes in the position of your head.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A cerebrovascular accident caused by bleeding or blockage in the brain's blood vessels, leading to potentially lasting symptoms, including weakness, paralysis, and sensory deficits like vertigo and double vision.

diagnoses: Poisoning (e.g., with heavy metals such as mercury or lead)
Vertigo of central or peripheral origin

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe, recurrent headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, with associated symptoms such as eye watering and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Tension Headaches
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by pressure or tightness around the forehead or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Weakness is a common symptom, and headaches can occur.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause visual disturbances (including scotoma), weakness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain, which can cause headache, vision problems, and can be life-threatening if it ruptures.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the brain without a detectable cause, leading to headache, vision problems, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Crisis
diagnoses.description: A severe increase in blood pressure that can lead to headache, severe anxiety, shortness of breath, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in certain vitamins, such as B12, can cause neurological symptoms including headache, weakness, and sensory disturbances.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)
Metabolic Disorders such as Vitamin B12 Deficiency
Infectious diseases (e.g., Hepatitis C associated with lichen planus)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, manifesting in a wide array of symptoms such as rash, arthritis, and neuropsychiatric disorders.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that occurs as a reaction to certain prescription drugs, with symptoms that can include skin rash, joint pain, and occasionally neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Cerebritis
diagnoses.description: A severe neurological manifestation of SLE that can present with symptoms including psychosis, delirium, seizures, and cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also involve other organs leading to diverse symptoms such as arthritis and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet, and can have systemic manifestations such as fatigue and lung involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, potentially involving internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder featuring a combination of symptoms of systemic autoimmune diseases like SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, with patients experiencing features like swollen hands, joint pain, and Raynaud's phenomenon.

diagnoses.name: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
diagnoses.description: Psychosis can be secondary to other medical conditions, such as systemic infections, endocrine disorders, and brain injuries or tumors.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause symptoms depending on which organs are affected but can include rash, arthritis, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A complication of untreated syphilis that can affect the brain and nervous system, leading to symptoms such as psychosis, delirium, and cognitive deterioration.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C associated with cryoglobulinemia)
Viral infections (such as HIV or Hepatitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
HIV/AIDS with Opportunistic Infection or Malignancy
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
